title: Nuclear decay - compare times 1e20 to 1e19 to 1e18

content.question:
Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A radioactive sample decays over time, as described.

At time <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>: <math alttext="1 times 10 raised to the twentieth power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>20</mn></msup></math> nuclei are in the sample.

At time <math alttext="t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>: <math alttext="1 times 10 raised to the nineteenth power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>19</mn></msup></math> original nuclei are in the sample.

At time <math alttext="t sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>: <math alttext="1 times 10 raised to the eighteenth power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>18</mn></msup></math> original nuclei are in the sample.

(a) Consider time intervals <math alttext="delta t sub 1 0, end sub, equals t sub 1, end sub, minus 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>10</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>-</mo><mn>0</mn></math> and <math alttext="delta t sub 2 1, end sub, equals t sub 2, end sub, minus t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>21</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>.

Indicate whether <math alttext="delta t sub 2 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>21</mn></msub></math> is greater than, less than, or equal to <math alttext="delta t sub 1 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>10</mn></msub></math>.

_____<math alttext="delta t sub 2 1, end sub, is greater than delta t sub 1 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>21</mn></msub><mo>></mo><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>10</mn></msub><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace></math>_____<math alttext="delta t sub 2 1, end sub, is less than delta t sub 1 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>21</mn></msub><mo><</mo><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>10</mn></msub><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace></math>_____<math alttext="delta t sub 2 1, end sub, is equal to delta t sub 1 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>21</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>10</mn></msub><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace></math>

Justify your answer without manipulating equations.

frqParts.text:
Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A radioactive sample decays over time, as described.

At time <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>: <math alttext="1 times 10 raised to the twentieth power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>20</mn></msup></math> nuclei are in the sample.

At time <math alttext="t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>: <math alttext="1 times 10 raised to the nineteenth power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>19</mn></msup></math> original nuclei are in the sample.

At time <math alttext="t sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>: <math alttext="1 times 10 raised to the eighteenth power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>18</mn></msup></math> original nuclei are in the sample.

(a) Consider time intervals <math alttext="delta t sub 1 0, end sub, equals t sub 1, end sub, minus 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>10</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>-</mo><mn>0</mn></math> and <math alttext="delta t sub 2 1, end sub, equals t sub 2, end sub, minus t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>21</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>.

Indicate whether <math alttext="delta t sub 2 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>21</mn></msub></math> is greater than, less than, or equal to <math alttext="delta t sub 1 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>10</mn></msub></math>.

_____<math alttext="delta t sub 2 1, end sub, is greater than delta t sub 1 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>21</mn></msub><mo>></mo><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>10</mn></msub><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace></math>_____<math alttext="delta t sub 2 1, end sub, is less than delta t sub 1 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>21</mn></msub><mo><</mo><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>10</mn></msub><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace></math>_____<math alttext="delta t sub 2 1, end sub, is equal to delta t sub 1 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>21</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>10</mn></msub><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace></math>

Justify your answer without manipulating equations.

A radioactive sample has decay constant <math alttext="lambda" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>λ</mi></math>. At <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, the sample has <math alttext="N" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>N</mi></math> nuclei. Time <math alttext="t sub the fraction, 1 over x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mfrac bevelled="true"><mn>1</mn><mi>x</mi></mfrac></msub></math> is the time at which the number of original nuclei remaining in the sample is <math alttext="the fraction with numerator N, and denominator x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mi>N</mi><mi>x</mi></mfrac></math>.
(b) Derive an expression for <math alttext="t sub the fraction, 1 over x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mfrac bevelled="true"><mn>1</mn><mi>x</mi></mfrac></msub></math> in terms of <math alttext="lambda" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>λ</mi></math>, <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math> and physical constants, as appropriate. Begin your derivation by writing a fundamental physics principle or an equation from the reference information.
(c) State whether the equation derived in part (b) is or is not consistent with your answer provided in part (a). Briefly justify your answer.

skill.text: 2.A: Derive a symbolic expression from known quantities by selecting and following a logical mathematical pathway.
